data.name: Sixty Cycles, Endless Legacy: Centennial Special Exhibition of the National Palace Museum
data.description: The National Palace Museum carries not only cultural artifacts but also a collective memory that transcends eras. The year 2025 marks several important milestones in the museum’s history: the 100th anniversary since its transformation in 1925 from an imperial collection into a museum shared by the public; the 75th anniversary of the artifacts’ relocation to Taiwan and their preservation in the Beigou repository beginning in 1950; the 60th anniversary since the establishment of the National Palace Museum in Taiwan in 1965; and the 10th anniversary of the Southern Branch, which opened in 2015. At this moment of overlapping centennial and cyclical milestones, the museum presents the special exhibition “Sixty Cycles, Endless Legacy,” reflecting on the achievements of the past sixty years while envisioning the boundless possibilities of the future through a century of accumulated heritage.

img_key_vision.name: exhibition_kv
img_key_vision.alt_text: Key visual image of the exhibition 'Sixty Cycles, Endless Legacy: Centennial Special Exhibition of the National Palace Museum'

work_binding.name: Illustrated Scenes from Dream of the Red Chamber
Qing Dynasty, Qianlong Reign — Gold and East Pearl Adorned Court Lady’s Headdress Finial with Cat’s-Eye Stone
Late Ming to Qing — Bronze Censer, Vase, and Box with Kui Dragon Motifs
Echoes of the Song Dynasty — Ru Ware and Ding Ware
Yuan Dynasty — Blue-and-White Cup and Saucer
Yuan Dynasty — Jun Ware Sky-Blue Glazed Bowl with Purple Splashes

works.name: Illustrated Poems of *Dream of the Red Chamber*
works.description:
Written by Gai Qi, Qing dynasty
Illustrated woodblock-printed book, published in the 5th year of the Guangxu reign (1879)
National Palace Museum catalog nos. 003571—003574
Height: 22.5 cm; Width: 15 cm

Much about Cao Xueqin remains shrouded in mystery. After the Cao family fell from power and its property was confiscated, Cao Xueqin—overwhelmed by sorrow—returned to Beijing. In 1762, on New Year's Eve of the renwu year (the 27th year of the Qianlong reign), he passed away “before reaching the age of fifty, his tears exhausted while the book remained unfinished.” Our understanding of his short life and his incomplete *Dream of the Red Chamber* is often fragmentary, as if his very existence were a riddle.

Yet the novel’s unfinished state has never diminished its allure. If anything, its open-endedness inspired generations of readers, giving rise to numerous editions, commentaries, and pictorial interpretations such as this illustrated work.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Illustrated Poems of Dream of the Red Chamber: A book cover design featuring a fine-line drawing of two figures in traditional attire standing beside a large rock. To the right runs a vertical title strip with black characters framed by decorative triangular corners. The layout clearly separates the illustration on the left from the title panel on the right.

works.name: Gold Headdress Finial Set with Eastern Pearls and Cat’s-Eye Stone for an Imperial Consort, Qing dynasty, Qianlong reign
works.description:
NPM collection no. 4837
Height: 16 cm; Base diameter: 4.8 cm

Yuanfei, whose formal name is Jia Yuanchun, is the elder sister of Jia Baoyu. Entering the palace at the age of thirteen or fourteen, she later rose to the rank of Imperial Consort, bringing the Jia family to the height of its glory. The practice of "returning home to observe filial piety" allowed imperial consorts to leave the palace temporarily to visit their parents and elders. To welcome Yuanchun on such an occasion, the Jia family constructed the Grand View Garden.

The Grand View Garden becomes many things at once: a fleeting paradise where Yuanchun briefly reunites with her family yet remains forever separated from her youth; a secluded world where Baoyu and the young maidens live under the protective shadow of her imperial status; and, ultimately, a lost eden—Cao Xueqin’s elegy for a bygone age of prosperity and tenderness.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Qianlong-period gold headdress finial with layered openwork design; the hemispherical gold base is adorned with intricate patterns, supporting multiple tiers of curled and pierced gold elements in bird and foliage motifs. Set with round Eastern pearls throughout, topped by an oval cat’s-eye gemstone of warm yellow-brown hue.

works.name: Bronze Censer, Vase, and Box with Gui Motifs, Late Ming to Qing dynasty
works.description:
NPM collection nos. 1565, 1820, 1819
Censer height: 15 cm; Vase height: 13.8 cm; Box height: 7.9 cm

A faint thread of fragrance seems to drift through every page of *Dream of the Red Chamber*. Incense is burned not only in grand ceremonies, but also during the Jia household’s daily routines. When the Imperial Consort Yuanchun returns home for her ceremonial visit, lilies are burned in great braziers throughout the Grand View Garden. At family banquets, the Jia clan sets out the elegant trio of censer, vase, and box on the table, using them to burn the imperial “Lily Palace Incense.”

This set of three—censer, incense box, and utensil vase—forms a complete ensemble. The censer is used for burning incense; the box stores incense; and the vase holds tools such as tongs and scoops. Arranged with the censer in the center and the box and vase to either side, the censer takes pride of place. The censer mentioned in the novel, known as the *Wenwang ding*, derives from bronze ritual vessels used in ceremonies honoring King Wen of Zhou. Frequently imitated in the Ming and Qing periods, such archaistic pieces were treasured as refined objects suited to the contemplative atmosphere of the scholar’s studio.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Bronze censer, vase, and box set on a carved wooden stand. The vase at left has a slender neck and holds incense tools; the central tripod censer features gilded surfaces with blue-green geometric bands; and the round lidded box at right displays matching decoration. The three pieces form a ritual-like arrangement reminiscent of traditional incense sets.

works.name: In the Style of the Song: Ru Ware and Ding Ware
works.description:
NPM collection no. 17854
Mouth diameter: 15.7 cm; Height: 3.7 cm

Porcelain used in everyday life throughout *Dream of the Red Chamber* frequently evokes the celebrated kilns of the Song dynasty—Ru ware and Ding ware—as well as renowned imperial kilns of the Ming, such as Xuande and Chenghua. These refined objects embellish both the Jia household and the Grand View Garden. For Cao Xueqin, such elegance was embedded in memory: exquisite antique ceramics, alongside Qing-period archaistic wares, form the backdrop of the world he reimagined.

Ru ware—“as precious as the morning star”—appears repeatedly in the novel in the form of dishes, vases, and flower vessels. Ding ware—“the finest white under heaven”—is likewise present: at Baoyu’s birthday banquet, forty Ding ware dishes are used to serve delicacies and seasonal fruits. Quietly luxurious yet understated, these porcelains leave a lasting impression of the refined daily life they once adorned.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: A shallow circular dish coated in a soft bluish-grey glaze. The surface is covered with fine crackle patterns, and the gently rounded rim and neatly carved foot give the piece an elegant, understated presence characteristic of Song-inspired ware.

works.name: Yuan Dynasty — Cobalt-Blue Cup with Single Handle
works.description: This cup has a funnel-shaped form with a metal rim at the mouth. The slanted body features a ring-shaped handle on one side. The base is carved into a recessed foot, left unglazed and coated with a yellowish-brown slip for protection. Except for the base, the entire surface is covered in a cobalt-blue glaze. Traces of once-present gold or silver foil decoration can still be faintly seen on the glaze. Below the inner rim is a band of lozenge-patterned squares, while the center of the interior displays a twelve-pointed star rosette. A single branch of plum blossoms encircles the exterior wall.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Yuan Dynasty Cobalt-Blue Single-Handled Cup: A deep-blue, funnel-shaped cup with a slightly flared rim edged in metal. One side features a small rectangular loop handle. The glaze is smooth and richly colored.

audio_files.transcript: This cup has a funnel-shaped form with a metal rim at the mouth. The slanted body features a ring-shaped handle on one side. The base is carved into a recessed foot, left unglazed and coated with a yellowish-brown slip for protection. Except for the base, the entire surface is covered in a cobalt-blue glaze. Traces of once-present gold or silver foil decoration can still be faintly seen on the glaze. works.name: Yuan Dynasty — Jun Ware Bowl with Sky-Blue Glaze and Purple Splashes
works.description: This bowl features a slightly constricted, round mouth, deep curving walls, and a pointed base with a short ring foot. The glaze differs between the interior and exterior. Inside, the glaze is a sky-blue color, with the unglazed area at the base center showing a three-pronged support mark. The exterior is also sky-blue but displays cloud-like purple splashes within the glaze layer, resembling rosy clouds. The rim is accented with a band of reddish-brown. Parts of the ring foot are roughly finished, and the unglazed areas on the foot base, foot wall, and inner rim reveal the reddish earthen body. The slightly convex base is coated with sky-blue glaze.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Yuan Dynasty Jun Ware Bowl with Sky-Blue Glaze and Purple Splashes: A round ceramic bowl featuring soft gradient hues blending light blue, violet, and green. The rim slightly flares outward with a fine brown edge. The body is full and rounded with a small circular foot.

medias.name: work_image_main
medias.alt_text: Yuan Dynasty Jun Ware Bowl with Sky-Blue Glaze and Purple Splashes

audio_files.transcript: 斂圓口，深弧形壁，尖底並有矮圈足。釉色裏外不一致，內壁釉色為天藍色，底部中心處無釉，留有一塊三杈形的支痕。外壁釉色為天藍色但釉層中泛出猶如彩霞的紫色斑紋，口沿一道赭紅邊。圈足底緣修飾不完整，足底、圈足外壁及內周壁無釉處，皆露赭土色胎，外底心微凸，施天藍色釉彩。
